displayed_text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - you have a two out of three chance of getting the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately to that lymph node. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or you can have a one out of three chance to get in the observation group first. If you go in the observation group you’re gonna get no additional therapy. You’ll be getting your PSA checked every other month. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If there’s another increase by fifty percent of then Patient: Okay. What’s the timeframe for the observation? Are we talking like a six month period of observations or what you’re saying that if I for whatever was to receive the observation does that one day receive the observation that would just remain until I hit the forty-two which could be like it could be a year? Doctor: So that’s, so that’s where the Patient: Okay. Doctor: You raise a very good question. Then if you go with the observation group and the PSA would still rise

Family Member: Okay. Patient: June eighteen for the blood work? Doctor: Yes, from C____ sometime that week. Patient: Yeah right. pause]] Family Member: Now are his bloodwork test results available online? Doctor: No. We don’t have it an outpatient patient portal yet. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We have an inpatient one but you know that doesn’t apply to you. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So yeah. So now we have to do this phone and paper printout things. Which will change we are hoping sometime soon chuckles]]. Patient: Your kids done for the year? Doctor: Yeah they are.

Patient: It doesn’t blink. The eye’s not going to blink. But, you know. Doctor: Did they scan your brain or anything? Patient: I did a, I did a, in my, huh, in my, in my eye hit at the Doctor: Because it’s gotten worse. Patient: What? Doctor: I mean, your face is even- Patient: Well, one thing, I said the wrong side. It’s not the right side. It’s the left side. Doctor: Uh-huh. Patient: But I’m starting to think I . I wouldn’t even do that. Doctor: So it got a little worse from when you saw me but actually it hasn’t gotten worse in the last week or so? Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Okay. So there’s only one medicine on here that I’m looking at. Huh, do you take acyclovir? Did they put you on that? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I’m not, I’m not the one that can tell you. You have to use common sense. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s not like you’re going up north, you’re going to F__. Patient: Yeah, well Doc I went to C__. Doctor: I got ya, but that was way before you got sick. Patient: Well not really. Doctor: Okay, I’m just saying. Patient: You know I’m just saying doc, I doc, you know. Doctor: Yeah. That’s gonna be your decision. Okay. Family Member: Excuse me. Doctor: Yep, Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we talked about an MRI which would tell us more about your back to see if there's something in the middle of the bone that would be cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could look at a PET scan, which you know, PSA is over point seven. These PET scans can be pretty good about picking up things. And basically they're just looking at how tumors are growing and if they’re growing, then they light up. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that we can do one of those scans and see how much lights up. Usually what…I don't like these tests because they tend to find what's under the radar. Because we know there's disease-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So in this study there are two options. One option is patients get the Xtandi. That’s the same thing that I’ve written on the the top of this page. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Okay. So option number one is to get the same drug that I would have recommended anyway as part of your standard care. Option number two is the combination of Xtandi plus the new experimental drug, which has a long name. It’s called G__?___. And this second drug has been shown in the laboratory, not yet in patients but in the laboratory, that makes the Xtandi work better and longer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And one of the things that this drug does, although it does many other things as well, is that it can boost the immune system. So one of the reasons why cancer can grow and progress in a person’s body, is because the immune system isn’t able to attack and kill the cancer cells fast enough. And the cancer cells can make some chemicals that can switch off those immune cells. recognizing and killing the cancer. What this drug is it tries to stimulate that immune system again so it can recognize the cancer. But it does that in conjunction with the Xtandi. Now, I didn’t mention this before but this medication is also a pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Questions. Patient: Well, the first question is of course- Doctor: Yep. Patient: -is side effects. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that. Doctor: Oh, are you reading the consent? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, so you know what I mean. Doctor: Mmm. Didn’t they give you a bigger version before you go blind looking at your phone, because it's like 30 pages of that stuff- Patient: Yeah, yeah.

Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine. Doctor: Yeah, they won't be subtle when they decide to act tough. You're gonna feel it. It's not the occasional, Oh, that kind of hurts. It's the oh man this day hurts every day. Family Member: He has body aches, constantly, his whole body aches and I'm trying to figure out what's causing these body aches. It's like he sat there the other day and was telling me how he was feeling and I know this is terrible, but I started laughing because and I know I was not laughing at you. Yeah, I feel overwhelmed. Like there's nothing I can do. Patient: I’ve been going to a chiropractor for 15 years. Almost on a weekly basis Doctor: Yeah. Patient: To get my back adjusted. They adjust my upper back and my lower back and they adjust my neck. Family Member: But this all over body aching is how long. Patient: Who knows. Doctor: Since he’s been on Xtandi. Family Member: She buries her head. Doctor: That’s it I’m leaving. Family Member: Okay good. And she's going to explain about the trial? Doctor: And the schedule just to make sure it's something that you're even going to do.

Family Member: Yeah. I saw that this morning. Doctor: Oh, my. Family Member: North and south was shut down. Doctor: Oh, boy. Patient: No south of us Doctor: Yeah. It was police incident. I’m not sure exactly what they say it was but- Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing.

Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month? Doctor: Uh. Patient: Before you would start? Doctor: I mean, so we - in other studies, we’ve had up to about a four-month window that we could get the chemo started. In this study, it’s sorta that there is a definition, I think you said-- Healthcare Professional: It’s, umm. You’re talking about the protocols and parameters? Family Member: Yeah, the study itself. Doctor: Yeah. Thirty or sixty Healthcare Professional: Thirty days, I do believe. From the, um, the, the Doctor: From the hormone first Healthcare Professional: hormone first. Doctor: Right, so if he gets this hormone therapy on the twenty-first, then Healthcare Professional: On the twenty-first, then he could. December. Probably, uh, we could stretch it out to the end of December. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then at the end of the day you look at the outcomes and you see are the recurrence rates you know slowed down less in the patients that receive the Metformin or alternatively our prevention rates that with time those that don’t receive the Metformin. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they would ask about the dose as well. So at any rate, to answer your question that the advise on the Metformin is if you have another reason to be on it. Patient: Yes. Doctor: For example, if you have a slight gluco-spasm where the glucose is a little bit elevated or if you have you know clinical type two diabetes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Then it may also be beneficial for your prostate cancer, but the prostate cancer I wouldn’t say should be the primary reason for being on it. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Infusion. Yes. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: He invented that infusion. Doctor: Yes. Patient: So whatever happened to him? Doctor: I’m not sure if any one man invented it. So it’s a company called, D___, so it’s several scientists that have figured that out. I have no idea what’s happened to them but the company, you know, is still alive and well, and, they, we give the stuff all the time to people. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t think there’s a conspiracy. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: If that’s where you’re going. Family Member: Right. Yeah. Doctor: This is not a trial. It’s an FDA-approved study. Where there is a trial- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: - or a proven therapy that will slow the progression. So I know that. So thinking in terms of that uh if there was something else that was being done before we actually hit that, that’s almost like saying, “This is my little (laughs) Family Member: Right, right. Patient: You know to hold, you know while I try other things. Of course I have to go relying on your experience. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Uh hum. Patient: And that’s your level of expertise what you’re doing. You’re the oncologist. You know so I’m going to have to weigh… Doctor: Yeah. Sure. Patient: …when we make the decision, we’re going to have to weigh it on what what you’re telling us. Uh so you kind of know where I’m coming from. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: Um what is where you’re coming from at this point? What is it that you would suggest? What would - Doctor: I think there are like two broad ways to tackle this. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And at this point in time they are mutually exclusive. And in the future the two are probably going to be combined, but right now they are mutually exclusive. One is to give a radio therapy in the absence of hormone therapy. In other words try give you a non-hormonal treatment.

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: Uh we often see after folks have been on what is also known as Zytiga- Patient: I was on it. Doctor: Yeah. We get, we get sort of resistance that carries through there. Patient: Ohh. Doctor: So that means uh we need to take you off. I mean the testosterone part of this, the input of the study was PSA going down. So you already, you have gone up a little. So you already hit that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Previously, we’ve been letting people stay on the testosterone. They feel good plus their scans don’t look any worse. I think given that your PSA went up, you’re feeling good, and the scans are a little worse, maybe you should come off it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And think about what’s next. Patient: Yeah. What is next? Doctor: Yeah. That’s the hard part of the day. Uh well I guess the first question is you sort of came here specifically for this. Are you going to, do you want to stay here for the next or is the next, do you want to go somewhere, to shop around?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Where it would have been an issue is if you’d gotten so much that you didn’t have any bone marrow reserve left, you know, like you’re perpetually having a low red blood cell count and need a blood transfusion but that’s not you so it’s something we consider but definitely not something we have to fuss about with you. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Just so you know cost wise, you know, no one ponies up money to just do this because, you know, you’re used to having the high ticket items for Zytiga and Xtandi but this is about fifteen thousand a dose so insurance has to clear it because that’s just the drug cost not everything else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, in that sense you might see a bigger invoice, you know, at the end of it but most insurance companies cover it in whole Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did.
